links.title: Mail::RFC822::Address Regex
links.description:
According to the RFC-822 of mail address validation, there is a monster PERL-based Regular Expression with actually so many errors when I tried to use it in online regex testers:

(?:(?:\r\n)?[ \t]...

links.title: Mail::RFC822::Address
links.description:
Mail::RFC822::Address is a Perl module to validate email addresses according to
the RFC 822
grammar.  It provides the same functionality as RFC::RFC822::Address, but uses
Perl regular expressions rather that the Parse::RecDescent parser.  This means
that the module is much faster to load as it does not need to compile the
grammar on startup.

links.title: NVCell: Standard Cell Layout in Advanced Technology Nodes with Reinforcement Learning | Research
links.description: High quality standard cell layout automation in advanced technology nodes is still challenging in the industry today because of complex design rules. In this paper we introduce an automatic standard cell layout generator called NVCell that can generate layouts with equal or smaller area for over 90% of single row cells in an industry standard cell library on an advanced technology node. NVCell leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to fix design r...

links.title: Is WebAssembly faster than JavaScript?
links.description: Most programs running on web sites are written in JavaScript. There are still a few Java applets and other plugins hanging around, but they are considered obsolete at this point. While JavaScript is superbly fast, some people feel that we ought to do better. That’s where WebAssembly comes in. It is a binary (“pre-compiled”) format … Continue reading Is WebAssembly faster than JavaScript?

links.title: Boosting WebAssembly Performance with SIMD and Multi-Threading
links.description:
Early implementations of WebAssembly's SIMD and multi-threading proposals show that WebAssembly is narrowing the gap with native performance, by using  SIMD instructions and multicore CPUs. 
Significant performance improvements have been observed in compute-intensive tasks (machine-learning, bio-informatics, scientific computing).

I didn't see a way to do this currently.

Example, you have a several different plan scenarios already created.  Now you want to add a new income/expense/asset/etc - let's say you decide you want to simulate adding a new dependent.  You want to see how this affects all of your existing financial plans.  Currently you have to manually add this dependent to each financial plan independently.

links.title: Distributed Systems Safety Research
links.description:
Jepsen is an effort to improve the safety of distributed databases, queues,
consensus systems, etc. We maintain an open source software
library for systems testing, as well as blog
posts and conference
talks exploring particular systemsâ
failure modes. In each analysis we explore whether the system lives up to its
documentationâs claims, file new bugs, and suggest recommendations for
operators.

links.title: Planting Undetectable Backdoors in Machine Learning Models
links.description:
Given the computational cost and technical expertise required to train
machine learning models, users may delegate the task of learning to a service
provider. We show how a malicious learner can plant an undetectable backdoor
into a classifier. On the surface, such a backdoored classifier behaves
normally, but in reality, the learner maintains a mechanism for changing the
classification of any input, with only a slight perturbation. Importantly,
...
links.original_title: Planting Undetectable Backdoors in Machine Learning Models

links.title: Turning Your Weakness Into a Strength: Watermarking Deep Neural Networks by Backdooring
links.description:
Deep Neural Networks have recently gained lots of success after enabling
several breakthroughs in notoriously challenging problems. Training these
networks is computationally expensive and requires vast amounts of training
data. Selling such pre-trained models can, therefore, be a lucrative business
model. Unfortunately, once the models are sold they can be easily copied and
redistributed. To avoid this, a tracking mechanism to identify models as...

links.title: Tetris is NP-hard even with $O(1)$ rows or columns
links.description:
We prove that the classic falling-block video game Tetris (both survival and
board clearing) remains NP-complete even when restricted to 8 columns, or to 4
rows, settling open problems posed over 15 years ago [BDH+04]. Our reduction is
from 3-Partition, similar to the previous reduction for unrestricted board
sizes, but with a better packing of buckets. On the positive side, we prove

links.title: The Shape of Rome – Ex Urbe

links.title: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision
links.description:
State-of-the-art computer vision systems are trained to predict a fixed set
of predetermined object categories. This restricted form of supervision limits
their generality and usability since additional labeled data is needed to
specify any other visual concept. Learning directly from raw text about images
is a promising alternative which leverages a much broader source of
supervision. We demonstrate that the simple pre-training task of predictin...

links.title: Manifold Matching via Deep Metric Learning for Generative Modeling - Microsoft Research
links.description: We propose a manifold matching approach to generative models which includes a distribution generator (or data generator) and a metric generator. In our framework, we view the real data set as some manifold embedded in a high-dimensional Euclidean space. The distribution generator aims at generating samples that follow some distribution condensed around the real data […]

links.title: Tackling the Generative Learning Trilemma with Denoising Diffusion GANs
links.description: To reduce the number of sampling steps in diffusion models, we propose to model the denoising distribution with conditional GANs. We show our model tackles the generative learning trilemma & achieves high sample quality, diversity & fast sampling.
